title: The scandal that keeps haunting Goldman Sachs
text:
One scoop to start: Everton Football Club is in talks to secure new financing after suspending sponsorships with companies connected to sanctioned Russian billionaire Alisher Usmanov, people with knowledge of the matter told the FT's Samuel Agini.

Cake and conspiracy: the 1MDB trial barrels on

Tim Leissner “wanted to be a hero at Goldman Sachs”, he said in a Manhattan courtroom last week.

When a prosecutor asked the former banker what fate he hopes to receive now, he responded: “I hope I don't have to go to prison, sir.”

The same stunning reversal in ambition also applies to Roger Ng, the ex-Goldman banker who was once Leissner's subordinate and is on trial for fraud over Malaysia's 1MDB scandal.

For DD readers needing a refresh on the multibillion-dollar pillage of the Malaysian state investment fund, we broke down the saga here. Goldman has said it was lied to by Malaysian officials and 1MDB, while Leissner has testified to lying to the bank during its internal review of 1MDB transactions.

A lot has happened since then. Ng, Goldman's former head of investment banking in Malaysia, is on trial for conspiring to launder money and violate an anti-bribery law, charges for which he pled not guilty.

US prosecutors claim he received more than $35mn in funds misappropriated from the 1MDB fund for his role in bribing officials and moving stolen money to offshore bank accounts. Marc Agnifilo, Ng's lawyer, said the banker had “nothing to do” with the $35mn payment.

They've also accused Ng of cultivating close ties to Malaysian financier Jho Low, the alleged mastermind behind the fraud who remains at large and denies wrongdoing. Agnifilo has sought to focus on Leissner's own relationship with the financier, which continued after the banker left Goldman.

Both men face significant prison time — up to 30 years for Ng and up to 25 for Leissner, who has agreed to co-operate with the US government in the hope of receiving a lesser sentence.

The former Goldman south-east Asia chair has already pleaded guilty for his role in the conspiracy. He's admitted to spending his roughly $60mn share of the stolen proceeds on luxuries including a 170ft yacht and investments in Italian football team Inter Milan.

His testimony now threatens to drag down Ng — along with Malaysian politicians and Abu Dhabi government officials.

One interesting titbit: the two used code words on BlackBerry messenger while concocting the scheme, Leissner alleged, using “cakes” to refer to money owed to the “bakery” — aka those who were promised bribes.

But Leissner hasn't proved himself to be particularly trustworthy, something Ng's lawyers have latched on to throughout his account of events.

The defence attempted to poke multiple holes in Leissner's story, such as his version of a meeting with Low, Ng and others during which the two discussed receiving potential kickbacks. The problem, according to Ng's attorney: Leissner had booked a flight to Hong Kong that night.

Leissner's personal life is just as tangled. He testified to Photoshopping divorce papers so he could marry his now-estranged wife, former model Kimora Lee Simmons, and to being temporarily engaged to the niece of a Malaysian state's chief minister while married to another woman.

Now Leissner, deemed by the defence as “a rare, cunning liar”, insists that it's “time to do the right thing”. 

With at least two more weeks of the trial to go, Ng's future could depend on whether his former boss can convince the jury that he has finally chosen the righteous path.

AMC strikes gold

Of the myriad strange things that DD didn't expect to happen this year, meme-ified cinema chain AMC Entertainment taking a stake in a gold mine would have been pretty high on the list.

On Tuesday, the cinema chain took a step in an unexpected direction, buying a 22 per cent stake in Nevada-based miner Hycroft Mining Holding Corporation.

The surprising link between both parties is Hycroft's largest shareholder, the New York-based hedge fund Mudrick Capital.

Mudrick lent hundreds of millions of dollars to AMC and also netted a quick profit from buying and rapidly selling its shares last summer.

It also had a role in Hycroft's tumultuous history. The mining company fell into bankruptcy in 2015, emerged later that year, and then went public via a merger with a Spac launched by Mudrick's founder Jason Mudrick during the peak of the blank-cheque boom in June 2020.

AMC is spending $27.9mn for 22 per cent of Hycroft — an investment matched by billionaire metals investor Eric Sprott. As part of the financing, Hycroft also has a deal with Sprott Resource Lending, the investor's private lending arm, to roll up its principal debt into a single payment due in 2027.

The odd deal could be the beginning of a greater foray by AMC into meme-stock companies.

Chief executive Adam Aron acknowledged the strangeness of the transaction: “To state the obvious, one would not normally think that a movie theatre company's core competency includes gold or silver mining.” 

He added that AMC's “enormous success . . . as well as communicating with individual retail investors” are skills that will be used to help Hycroft boost its share price.

The tactic appears to be working. Hycroft's shares jumped 13 per cent while AMC's rose 7 per cent.

As Lex notes, the hype may be enough for the Redditors. Day-traders boasting of “diamond hands” have suddenly found themselves holding gold and silver too.

UniCredit's dealmaking strategy takes another hit

Less than 12 months ago, DD might've put money on Andrea Orcel to lift Italy's UniCredit out of its rut.

When he took the helm of the Italian lender in April 2021, the kick-boxing banker had the support of UniCredit's politically fraught board on his side — which had previously clashed with his predecessor Jean Pierre Mustier.

But Orcel has been dealt a one-two punch that has put him on the defensive.

His first order of business to orchestrate a takeover of Italy's Banca Monte dei Paschi di Siena crumbled in October. More recently, the war in Ukraine has foiled UniCredit's attempt to buy Otkritie — a Russian bank now subject to western sanctions — and further weighed on its shares.

Prospects for a rumoured takeover of smaller Italian lender Banco BPM — in line with UniCredit's domestic M&A strategy — are looking grim, as Lex noted.

On Monday, Orcel announced that he's pondering an exit from Russia, in line with rivals JPMorgan Chase, Goldman and Deutsche Bank, after warning it could lose up to €7bn should its Russian business be wiped out in an “extreme scenario”.

Looks like the boisterous Orcel could be in for his biggest fight yet.

Job moves

  • GlaxoSmithKline has appointed six directors to the board of its new consumer health division Haleon, which is about to be spun off from its parent company.

  • Credit Suisse has named Rob Cox, the global editor of Reuters' Breakingviews, as group head of corporate communications.

  • Andreessen Horowitz has hired former federal prosecutor Michele Korver as its new regulatory head. She was previously the US Treasury's first chief digital currency adviser.

  • Allison Herren Lee, a commissioner at the Securities and Exchange Commission, is stepping down from the US regulator once her term ends in June.

  • Hipgnosis Song Management has appointed Markku Lonnqvist as chief investment officer. He was previously a partner at private equity fund Pamplona Capital Management.

  • KKR has appointed Lindsey Wright as a managing director and head of investment services for the private equity firm's US real estate credit business. She was previously senior managing director of asset management at Greystone.

  • General Atlantic has hired former Guardian Media Group chief executive Annette Thomas as a senior adviser based in London.

Smart reads

Got oat milk? Oatly doesn't. The Swedish vegan milkmaker got the world hooked on its frothy formula. But crippling supply issues have led its customers to reach for competitors, The Wall Street Journal reports.

Law and order Former FBI agent Bill McMurray has overseen massive corruption cases including Malaysia's 1MDB and Brazil's Odebrecht. He looks back on an extraordinary career in this interview with Project Brazen's Whale Hunting newsletter.

Dirty laundry Britain is busy at work sorting through laundered money. This Bloomberg report, in which an Azeri politician was able to buy two luxury flats while his family's UK bank accounts were under investigation, offers a case study in what not to do.
